facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 6/7, 1971 of the Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 619 of 1971.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 6/7, 1971 of the Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 619 of 1971. V. Gupte and P. N. Tiwari, for the appellants. S. Chawla, S. N. Mishra and S. S. Jauhar, for the respondents.

facts.text: Revisional court (Bench of Court of Small Causes Bombay) reversed the decision of the trial court and remanded the matter for disposal of issues other than issues 2 to 8.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave from a judgment and order of the Bombay High Court in a Special Civil Application from a decision. of the Court of Small Causes Bombay in exercise of its revisionary jurisdiction. The revisional companyrt had reversed the decision of the trial companyrt and remanded the matter for disposal ,of the issues other than issues 2 to 8 tried as preliminary issues and decided in favour of the plaintiffs before the Court of Small Causes.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 was the owner of a flat on the second floor of Block No. 8 Shyam Niwas, Warden Road, Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The facts are as follows. Respondent No. 1 was the owner of a flat on the second floor of Block No. 8 Shyam Niwas, Warden Road, I Bombay. She was a member of a Co-operative Housing Society and had acquired the flat from the said society.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 was a member of a Co-operative Housing Society and had acquired the flat from the said society.

anchor.surface_text: Bombay. She was a member of a Co-operative Housing Society and had acquired the flat from the said society. In 1959 she had put the appellant Sabharwal Brothers in possession of the flat for a period of 11 months on payment of Rs. 510/ - per month.

facts.text: In 1959 Respondent No. 1 put the appellant Sabharwal Brothers in possession of the flat for a period of 11 months on payment of Rs. 510 per month.

anchor.surface_text: In 1959 she had put the appellant Sabharwal Brothers in possession of the flat for a period of 11 months on payment of Rs. 510/ - per month. There was an agreement in writing which purported to show that the possession was to be on leave and licence basis.

facts.text: There was a written agreement showing possession on leave and licence basis, signed by a partner of Sabharwal Brothers who became member of the Co-operative Society.

anchor.surface_text: There was an agreement in writing which purported to show that the possession was to be on leave and licence basis. This agreement was signed by a partner of Sabharwal Brothers who also became member of the said Co-operative Society.

facts.text: Repeated renewals of the agreement until 25th October 1962.

anchor.surface_text: There were repeated renewels of the said agreement until 25th October, 1962 when the first respondent asked the appellants to vacate possession on the ground that she required the flat for her personal occupation.

facts.text: On 25th October 1962, first respondent asked appellants to vacate for her personal occupation.

anchor.surface_text: until 25th October, 1962 when the first respondent asked the appellants to vacate possession on the ground that she required the flat for her personal occupation. As this was number companyplied with, she filed a statement of claim before the Registrar of Co-operative Societies

facts.text: First respondent filed statement of claim before Registrar of Co-operative Societies under s.91 of Maharashtra Co-operative Societies Act as dispute.

anchor.surface_text: As this was number companyplied with, she filed a statement of claim before the Registrar of Co-operative Societies on the ground that there was a dispute within the meaning of s. 91  1  of the Maharashtra Co-operative Societies Act  Thereinafter referred to as the Act  which required adjudication

facts.text: Appellants challenged jurisdiction of nominee of Registrar.

anchor.surface_text: There was a challenge to the jurisdiction of the numberinee of the Registrar to whom it was referred by the appellants. The proceedings before the numberinee went on for some time on July 3, the numberinee made an award to the effect the, appellants were occupying the flat on leave and licence basis.

facts.text: On July 3, nominee made award that appellants were occupying on leave and licence basis.

anchor.surface_text: The proceedings before the numberinee went on for some time on July 3, the numberinee made an award to the effect the, appellants were occupying the flat on leave and licence basis. Anticipating the award the appellants filed a suit in the Court of Small Causes Bombay

facts.text: Appellants filed suit in Court of Small Causes Bombay claiming occupation as tenants entitled to protection under Bombay Rent Act 1947.

anchor.surface_text: Anticipating the award the appellants filed a suit in the Court of Small Causes Bombay stating that they were in occupation of the flat as tenants and as such entitled to protection under the Bombay Rent Act, 1947 and the first respondent had numberright to evict them.

facts.text: Defendant denied plaintiffs were tenants, contended leave and licence, dispute referred to Registrar, no jurisdiction in Small Causes Court.

anchor.surface_text: In her written statement the defendant denied that the plaintiffs were tenants companytending, inter alia, that the plaintiffs were occupying the flat only on leave and licence basis etc. that the dispute between the parties had been referred to the Registrar of Co-operative Societies for disposal and finally that the Court of Small Causes had numberjurisdiction to entertain and try a suit involving such a dispute.

facts.text: Small Causes Court framed 12 issues, issues 2 to 8 on maintainability and jurisdiction under s.91(1)(d) of Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Small Causes-Court framed numberless than twelve issues of which issues 2 to 8 related to the maintainability of the suit and the jurisdiction of the companyrt in view of the provisions of s. 91  1   d  of the Act. The Small Causes Court held that the suit was maintainable and answered the other preliminary issues in favour of the plaintiff.

facts.text: Small Causes Court held suit maintainable, answered preliminary issues 2-8 in favour of plaintiffs.

anchor.surface_text: The Small Causes Court held that the suit was maintainable and answered the other preliminary issues in favour of the plaintiff. The matter was taken in revision to a Bench of the said Small Causes Court.

facts.text: Bench of Small Causes Court in revision held Registrar's nominee had jurisdiction, remanded for res judicata issue.

anchor.surface_text: The Bench took a different view holding that the Registrars numberinee did have jurisdiction to try the dispute between the parties and remanded the proceedings to the trial companyrt for disposal of the suit after deciding on issue as to res judicata by reason of the award of the numberinee.

facts.text: Bombay High Court dismissed Special Civil Application of plaintiffs.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dismissed the Special Civil Application of the plaintiffs holding that the revisional companyrt of the Small Causes was justified in companying to the companyclusion that- it was number open to the plaintiffs to companytend that the Registrar or his numberinee had numberjurisdiction

facts.text: Bye-law No. 2 of Society: objects include trade of buying, selling, hiring and letting land per co-operative principles.

anchor.surface_text: Before the Court of Small Causes reference was made to bye- law No. 2 of the Society to show that the objects of the society were inter alia to carry on the trade of buying,selling, hiring and letting land in accordance with the companyoperative principles

facts.text: Regulation No. 5: No tenant shall assign, underlet, vacate or part with possession without society's written consent.

anchor.surface_text: and under Regulation No. 5 in form A printed at the end of the bye-laws No tenant shall assign, underlet, vacate or part with the possession of the tenement or any part thereof without the companysent in writing of the society.

facts.text: Bench of Small Causes observed letting dispute touches business of society as breach affects membership.

anchor.surface_text: The Bench of the Court of Small Causes referred to the above provisions and observed that the bye-laws of the society companystituted an agreement between the members of the society and a breach thereof would affect the defaulting members right of membership of the society

facts.text: Supreme Court held no dispute touching business of society, suit maintainable, allowed appeal.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we allow the appeal, set aside the judgement and order of the High Court And of the Bench of the Court of Small Causes.

facts.text: Letting by member to another member does not touch society's business.

anchor.surface_text: But we are number able to see how letting by a member to another member would touch the business of the society which included inter alia the trade of buying, selling, hiring and letting land in accordance with companyope- rative principles.

anchor.surface_text: Reference was made at the Bar to Deccan Merchants Co-operative Bank Ltd. v. M s Dalichand Jugraj Jain and others... the two acts can be harmonised best by holding that in matters covered

holdings.text: Letting by a member to another member does not touch the business of the society under s.91(1)(b) of the Maharashtra Co-operative Societies Act.

anchor.surface_text: But we are number able to see how letting by a member to another member would touch the business of the society which included inter alia the trade of buying, selling, hiring and letting land in accordance with companyope- rative principles.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Society's business refers to its own transactions like buying, selling, hiring, letting; private letting by member after acquiring flat from society does not affect or contact society's business.

holdings.text: The letting of the flat by respondent No.1 did not concern the business of the society.

anchor.surface_text: The letting of flat by respondent No. 1 was a transact-ion of the same nature as the society itself was empowered to enter into but such letting by itself did number companycern the business of the society in the matter of its letting out flats. Nothing was brought to our numberice to show that such a letting would affect the business of the society once it had sold the flat to the respondent No. 1.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Member's letting is private transaction similar to society's powers but does not impact society's business post-sale of flat; different if society were landlord.

holdings.text: There is no point of contact between a letting by respondent No.1 and the business of the society as 'to touch' means to come in contact with.

anchor.surface_text: To touch means to companye in companytact with and it does number appear that there is a point of companytact between a letting by the respondent No. 1 and the business of the society when the society was number itself the landlord of the flat.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interpret 'touching' literally as contact; no contact where society is not landlord.

holdings.text: The two Acts (Rent Act and Co-operative Societies Act) are harmonised by holding that in matters covered by the Rent Act, its provisions rather than the Co-operative Act's provisions apply.

anchor.surface_text: Reference was made at the Bar to Deccan Merchants Co-opera- tive Bank Ltd. v. M s Dalichand Jugraj Jain and others... the two acts can be harmonised best by holding that in matters companyered by the Rent Act, its provisions, rather than the provisions of the Act, should apply.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Deccan Merchants precedent, harmonious construction prioritises Rent Act over Co-operative Act for rent matters; resolves jurisdictional competition.

holdings.text: High Court's approach was fundamentally erroneous as there was no jurisdiction in Registrar's nominee.

anchor.surface_text: With all respect to the High Court, it seems to us that there was a fundamental error in the above approach.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Premised on incorrect assumption of jurisdiction under s.91; no referable dispute means no exclusive jurisdiction or finality to award.

holdings.text: Suit in Small Causes Court is maintainable; no bar under s.91(3) or s.163(1) as dispute not referable.

anchor.surface_text: Before us the main points urged on behalf of the appellants were first, whether there was any dispute between the parties touching the business of the Co-operative Society which companyld be decided by the Registrar or referred by him to a numberinee for disposal and, secondly whether the suit filed in the Small Causes Court was maintainable having regard to the nature of the relief sought.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Central question: dispute not capable of reference under Act, so civil court jurisdiction intact.
